title: The Uniformization Trichotomy
content:
The three types of simply connected Riemann surfaces form a complete classification:

1. **Elliptic/Spherical**: The Riemann sphere (compact, constant positive curvature)
2. **Parabolic**: The complex plane (non-compact, zero curvature)
3. **Hyperbolic**: The unit disk (non-compact, constant negative curvature)

Every simply connected Riemann surface is conformally equivalent to exactly one of these.
mathContext:
Classification: Simply Connected $\cong$ Sphere, Plane, or Disk

This trichotomy determines the geometry of the surface.

title: The Unit Disk
content:
The **open unit disk** $\mathbb{D} = \{z \in \mathbb{C} : |z| < 1\}$ is the most important of the three model spaces.

It uniformizes all hyperbolic Riemann surfaces, including all compact surfaces of genus $\geq 2$. The Poincare metric on $\mathbb{D}$ has constant Gaussian curvature $-1$.

title: Conformal Equivalence
content:
Two open sets $U, V \subset \mathbb{C}$ are **conformally equivalent** if there exists a bijective holomorphic map $f: U \to V$ with holomorphic inverse.

Conformal maps preserve angles and local shapes, but can distort distances. They are the natural isomorphisms in complex analysis.
mathContext:
$U \cong V$ conformally $\iff$ $\exists f: U \xrightarrow{\sim} V$ biholomorphic

Holomorphic functions with $f'(z) \neq 0$ are conformal.

title: Riemann Mapping Theorem
content:
The **Riemann Mapping Theorem** (1851, rigorous proof 1912):

Every simply connected proper open subset of $\mathbb{C}$ is conformally equivalent to the open unit disk.

This is the key stepping stone to the full Uniformization Theorem. The 'proper' condition (not all of $\mathbb{C}$) is essential: $\mathbb{C}$ itself is conformally equivalent to $\mathbb{C}$, not to the disk.
mathContext:
$U \subsetneq \mathbb{C}$ simply connected $\Rightarrow U \cong \mathbb{D}$

Uniqueness: The map is unique once we fix $f(z_0) = 0$ and $f'(z_0) > 0$.

title: The Uniformization Theorem
content:
**The Uniformization Theorem** (Koebe-Poincare, 1907):

Every simply connected Riemann surface is conformally equivalent to exactly one of:
- The Riemann sphere $\hat{\mathbb{C}}$
- The complex plane $\mathbb{C}$
- The unit disk $\mathbb{D}$

This completely classifies simply connected Riemann surfaces up to conformal equivalence.
mathContext:
Simply connected Riemann surface $S$ $\Rightarrow$
$S \cong \hat{\mathbb{C}}$ or $S \cong \mathbb{C}$ or $S \cong \mathbb{D}$

The type is determined by the growth of harmonic functions on $S$.

title: Fuchsian Groups
content:
A **Fuchsian group** is a discrete subgroup of $\text{PSL}(2,\mathbb{R})$, the group of orientation-preserving isometries of the hyperbolic plane.

Fuchsian groups act on the upper half-plane (or unit disk) by Mobius transformations. The quotient of the disk by a Fuchsian group is a hyperbolic Riemann surface.

title: Uniformization by Genus
content:
The uniformization type of a compact Riemann surface is determined by its **genus** $g$:

- $g = 0$: Uniformized by the Riemann sphere (spherical geometry)
- $g = 1$: Uniformized by $\mathbb{C}$ (flat geometry, tori)
- $g \geq 2$: Uniformized by the disk (hyperbolic geometry)

This connects topology (genus) to geometry (curvature).

title: Belyi's Theorem
content:
**Belyi's Theorem** (1979) provides a remarkable connection between uniformization and arithmetic:

A compact Riemann surface is defined over $\bar{\mathbb{Q}}$ (algebraic numbers) if and only if it admits a meromorphic function to $\mathbb{P}^1$ ramified over at most three points.

This connects complex geometry to Galois theory and dessins d'enfants.
mathContext: $S$ defined over $\bar{\mathbb{Q}}$ $\iff$ $\exists f: S \to \mathbb{P}^1$ with ramification $\subseteq \{0, 1, \infty\}$

title: Complete Resolution
content:
Hilbert's twenty-second problem is **completely solved** by the Uniformization Theorem.

Unlike some of Hilbert's problems that remain open or are independence results, this problem has a definitive affirmative answer: every Riemann surface can be uniformized by automorphic functions.

The theorem was proven independently by Koebe and Poincare in 1907, just seven years after Hilbert posed the problem.
mathContext:
Status: SOLVED (1907)

Koebe and Poincare: Two independent proofs
Modern proofs: Perron method, potential theory
